Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: The siblings are walking home from school together on a familiar street.
Expectation2: Show love and kindness to others, following the teachings of Jesus
Situation2: They notice someone in their circle going through difficulties and respond with care
Story: As we walked home from school, my stepbrother, Ethan, kicked a stone along the sidewalk, his backpack slung carelessly over one shoulder. I was supposed to look out for him—Mom always reminded me, “You’re the older one, keep him safe.” Halfway down Maple Street, we saw Jamie, a classmate, sitting alone on the curb, head in hands. I remembered what Pastor Lee said last Sunday: “Show love to those who are hurting, just as Jesus would.” I wanted to stop, to ask Jamie if he was okay, maybe offer to walk with him. But Ethan tugged at my sleeve, whispering, “Let’s go. He’s always weird. Mom said not to talk to strangers.” I hesitated, torn. My stepbrother needed me to keep him safe, to get him home on time, but my faith told me to reach out, to show kindness. My heart pounded as I stood between Ethan and Jamie, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which path to take.
